text: Stephen Lawrence inquiry was a watershed
moment for the police its Chair Sir
William Macpherson shocked many by
dubbing the Metropolitan Police
institutionally racist
Freddie no whacker was a young man then
now he's a father his encounters with
the police in London were difficult back
in the day there were very hands-on and
he was very much guilty of something
even if you hadn't done nothing so their
approach was very argumentative some of
the things that he had done if and the
way he had lived his past life I've
learned a lot from that his story
inspires me a lot so yeah I'll get a
passion of what I talk about I try I
tried to share a lot with him so that he
doesn't have to go through the things
that I win even even when it comes to
dealing with the police I've spoken to
him a lot of times about if they stop
you have to conduct yourself you haven't
done nothing wrong so just be polite
tensions flared at the inquiry when the
five white murder suspects gave evidence
men whom the police then had failed to
properly pursue and prosecute despite
numerous tip-offs disparities in police
treatment were put under the spotlight
including stop and search which black
people were five times more likely to
experience than white driving pastilla
the you know monkey chance or or the
n-word would would pop out it's one more
thing to kind of navigate in society
that's how the police used to treat
Roger Griffith he lives in Bristol as
does his son Lawrence City visited by
the inquiry Lawrence found stop and
search an ordeal I used to handle it
pretty bad I mean I used to get arrest
is quite frequently for just speaking my
mind and kind of like my dad said
rebelling against the police but
nowadays I just gave him my information
it's different
Freddie naka understands that anger
black people now a nine and a half times
as likely to be stopped and searched as
white people
police defend the tactics saying it
produces results as does Freddie who
thinks young black men have to accept it
I know at least five or six parents that
we lost their children to gun crime on
that ground we can always say it's wrong
and it's frustrating but I would much
rather the police stop and search a
hundred
children a day if it means gonna keep my
son safe and I'm saying it needs to feel
like we're stopping you to keep you safe
the exposure of police failings was
accompanied by recommendations by
McPherson for the future key among these
was that police services should reflect
their communities
Leroy Logan was a serving officer back
then and gave evidence to the inquiry
what was it like for him working in an
organization dubbed institutionally
racist those are supervising officer and
I was chair of the National Black Police
Association I sense a lot of deception
being said about me but I knew something
was going to happen you know you can't
push the boat out so far and it's not
gonna have ripple did his son miles ever
consider becoming a police officer even
though my father was a very big advocate
to get young black men into it yeah
personally I didn't I didn't want to get
involved because you didn't think this
was a place for you yeah I guess so yeah
definitely even if you look at the
streets nowadays it is a very white
european-based
force especially to interpret the city
that London is it doesn't show any
diversity this week the present-day
Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police
said the McPherson report had defined
her generation of policing a landmark
case for the police and minority
communities all triggered by the brutal
murder of one promising and innocent
young man
